text:
Just 33 days after
signing his first NBA contract

in 2009, Lanny Smith suffered
a career-ending knee injury.

Afterwards, he transitioned
to entrepreneurship,

and in 2020, he launched
an athleisure brand
called Actively Black.

Smith's company donates
a meaningful percentage

of its profits to
organizations and programs

that support Black communities
in the United States.

LANNY SMITH: The first
brand that I actually

launched is called active faith,
a faith-based sports apparel
brand.

Launched that brand out
of my mom's house in 2010,
had some great success with it.

Unfortunately, we
do have to deal
with the realities of society.

I was actually hiding myself
from people knowing that I was
the founder of Active Faith.

I was afraid that if they knew
it was this young Black male

that was the founder
that it would

have a negative impact
on the business.

And unfortunately, I
had multiple experiences
that supported that fear.

There was a group
that was emailing

in that had interest in possibly
investing in Active Faith

and go back and
forth over email,
set up the in-person meeting.

I'll never forget walking
through those doors

and just seeing the
looks on their faces.

They were shocked that it
was me, and all of a sudden,

they weren't interested
in investing anymore.

My parents raised me to
be proud of who I am,
to be proud of my culture.

To be hiding myself
for those reasons

was something that I
struggled with internally.

And so in 2018, the movie
Black Panther came out

and it shows the power
of representation.

That was my first
time really seeing

a superhero that looked
like me, and it was just
such a powerful thing.

And I saw the way
the Black community

and the entire diaspora
really came together

around Black Panther
and the movie.

I remember walking out
of the theater saying,

man, I want to
create a brand that

makes my people feel the way
that we felt in that movie.

When you make
something that makes

somebody feel a
certain type of way,

people might forget
what you say,

but they'll never forget
how you made them feel.

I think that's
part of the success

that we've had is people
are getting the product,

they're buying into the brand,
and how they feel changes.

One of my favorite
pieces of feedback I get

is when there's complete
strangers who are in an airport

or somewhere and they see each
other wearing Actively Black,

and then they have
a conversation.

They connect over them both
being part of this tribe.
There's power in that.

The negative images,
the oppression,

all the things that have
been-- the negative things that

have been attached
to being Black,

we're moving our
people away from that

and talking about the
greatness that lives within us.

The Nikes of the world,
the Adidas, the Puma,

et cetera, et cetera,
Nike wants you to be
a walking billboard for Nike.

They want you to wear the
swoosh across your chest

and be a walking
billboard for Nike.

The power and the
brand and what we're

building with Actively Black is
that my customers, the tribe,

they don't see themselves
as a walking billboard
for Actively Black.

They actually see Actively
Black as something
that is the billboard for them.

Giving back and impacting
our community is--

it's part of the why,
of why we're doing this.

In 2022, we did over
5 million in revenue.

We donated $500,000 back
into the Black community.
So that's 10% of our revenue.

When our audience also
sees that they're actually

about what they're
talking about,

like this isn't
just lip service,

they're actually putting
action behind it,

it continues to have
that compounding effect

because now we get those
comments all the time where

our customers are
like you know what.

I know that my money is
going to something that's

also going back into
my community that's
also helping somebody.

I don't mind spending this
money with Actively Black.
You know what I mean?

I want to spend my money
with Actively Black

because I know that
it's going for good.

That makes me-- that
makes me very proud,

and this is just the
beginning of that.

Some people will look at
you're serving a niche

audience as a
negative, but to me,
that's actually the positive.
Actually that is the unlock.

That is the way that you
stand out and give yourself
the best chance of success.

I can't compete with Nike
on research and development,

on R&D. We don't have
a budget for that.

I can't compete with them on the
technical side of the product.

Can't compete with them on
so many different things.

But I have a place where
Nike cannot compete with me.

They cannot out Black culture a
company that is literally built
from that.
That's our foundation.
That's who we are.

We are this 365 days
out of the year.

It's not just a Black
History Month collection

that Nike's going
to release that.
You know what I'm saying?
It's not just for Juneteenth.

Those giants cannot
compete in that space.
